Let me be clear ‚Äî my top priorities as Mayor of Los Angeles will be to get Angelenos housed, and to make our city safer and more affordable for all.

And that work has already begun.
I am living proof that a few devoted teachers can change the trajectory of a kid‚Äôs life.

Many people might look at where I started in life ‚Äî raised by a single mother in a family just a few generations removed from picking cotton ‚Äî and think it‚Äôs a pretty unfortunate circumstance.

But a good education was one opportunity I was never denied.

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to distinguish between teachers and the unions claiming to represent them.

We should never confuse the caring, capable people who have devoted themselves to this noble calling with self-interested labor bosses who exploit them for political ends.

Throughout my childhood, I had a number of teachers who didn‚Äôt just educate me, but championed me and cheered me on in almost every aspect of life.

They were mentors who helped shape my thinking today.

Teachers have one of the greatest callings on Earth.

In my experience, they care deeply about their students.

It‚Äôs teachers' unions, not teachers, who think they know what children need better than their own parents. 

And it‚Äôs teachers' unions, not teachers, who are waging political war against school choice, which empowers parents.

It‚Äôs clear that unions are the problem. Not teachers.
It was teachers‚Äô unions, not teachers, who labeled parents ‚Äúextremists‚Äù because they expressed concerns about what their children were being taught in schools.
It was teachers‚Äô unions, not teachers, who pressured the government to keep schools closed during the pandemic, resulting in devastating educational setbacks for America‚Äôs children.

Americans understand the difference between teachers and the union machines that use them as pawns.

Last year, a Gallup poll showed that 75% of Americans have confidence in public school teachers, but half think teachers‚Äô unions are hurting education.
